body_html:
@chenbiaolong Ah yes, the headers are all over the place. I made a shell script that can copy all the needed headers into a single location: https://gist.github.com/ilaripih/928ec17298859f168eee8d12cf796ee8

The script assumes that you have cloned and built tensorflow at /tensorflow, and can be run like this to copy the headers to /tf_headers:

sh bundle_tf_headers.sh /tf_headers

Then you can simply add /tf_headers/ and /tf_headers/third_party/eigen3/ as include paths to the linker.

The script probably only works with tensorflow 0.9

The script assumes that you have cloned and built tensorflow at /tensorflow, and can be run like this to copy the headers to /tf_headers:
sh bundle_tf_headers.sh /tf_headers
Then you can simply add /tf_headers/ and /tf_headers/third_party/eigen3/ as include paths to the linker.
The script probably only works with tensorflow 0.9
body:
@chenbiaolong  Ah yes, the headers are all over the place. I made a shell script that can copy all the needed headers into a single location: https://gist.github.com/ilaripih/928ec17298859f168eee8d12cf796ee8

The script assumes that you have cloned and built tensorflow at `/tensorflow`, and can be run like this to copy the headers to `/tf_headers`:

`sh bundle_tf_headers.sh /tf_headers`

Then you can simply add `/tf_headers/` and `/tf_headers/third_party/eigen3/` as include paths to the linker.

The script probably only works with tensorflow 0.9
